conclusion: Analyze the motion of oil droplets under gravity, air resistance, and electric field to determine the proportionality constant k.
Two oil droplets A and B each have a mass m_0 and fall with uniform velocity v_0 through a distance h_1 in time t.
Air resistance force on a droplet is given by f = k m^(1/3) v.
For droplet A and B falling with velocity v_0, f = k m_0^(1/3) v_0.
Gravitational force m_0 g is balanced by air resistance: m_0 g = k m_0^(1/3) v_0.
Simplifying the equilibrium condition gives g = k m_0^(-2/3) v_0.
When voltage U is applied, an electric field E = U/d is created between the plates.
Droplet B starts moving upwards with a uniform velocity v_1.
Electric force qE balances gravitational force and air resistance: qU/d = m_0 g + k m_0^(1/3) v_1.
Droplet B rises a distance h_2 in time t, giving v_1 = h_2/t.
Droplet B merges with A, forming a new droplet with mass 2m_0.
The new droplet reaches a uniform velocity v_2.
Forces on the combined droplet are balanced: qU/d = 2m_0 g + k (2m_0)^(1/3) v_2.
From the initial equilibrium condition, k = g/v_0 m_0^(2/3).
Using the relationship between v_0 and v_1: v_0 = h_1/t, v_1 = h_2/t.
Combining the equations and solving for k gives k = gt/(h_1 + h_2).
The proportionality constant k is given by k = gt/(h_1 + h_2).
